cells.data: Dictionaries are Pythons built in hash-table equivalent. Dictionaries operate off a series of ‘keys’. As seen below dictionaries are very powerful and very simple to implement.
If we want to access these values, you can use the key name itself, or if you don’t know the key names, you can export the values in the list into a list object.

personal = {
              'Name': 'Nicholas Dry',
              'Age': 21,
              'Location': 'New Jersey'
            }
            
print(personal['Name']) # This will print out the value with the key matching name

personalValues = personal.values()  # This will output as 'dict_values(['New Jersey', 'Nicholas Dry', 21])'

personalKeys = personal.keys()  # This will output as 'dict_keys(['Age', 'Name', 'Location'])'

for i in personalKeys:  # This will allow you to run through the list, assign the value to i, then search accordingly in the list
  print(personal[i])
